content.title: Hematuria Evaluation
content.summary: Hematuria (blood in urine) requires systematic evaluation to distinguish glomerular from non-glomerular sources and identify underlying pathology. The workup differs based on microscopic vs gross hematuria, patient age, and risk factors for malignancy. Key diagnostic steps include urinalysis with microscopy, imaging, and cystoscopy when indicated.
key_points: Microscopic hematuria: ≥3 RBCs/HPF on two separate UA specimens
Gross hematuria always warrants full urologic evaluation regardless of age
Dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts indicate glomerular origin
Cystoscopy recommended for patients ≥35 years or with risk factors
CT urography is preferred imaging for hematuria workup
content.statement: Hematuria evaluation is a systematic approach to identifying the source and etiology of blood in urine, differentiating glomerular from urologic causes, and guiding appropriate diagnostic workup including imaging and cystoscopy based on patient risk stratification.

explanation.intuition: Think of hematuria as a red flag that could indicate problems anywhere along the urinary tract - from glomeruli to urethra. Like a detective, you must trace the source: glomerular bleeding gives distorted (dysmorphic) RBCs after passing through the basement membrane, while urologic bleeding yields normal-looking (isomorphic) cells.
explanation.key_insight: The critical distinction is glomerular vs non-glomerular hematuria. Glomerular sources (dysmorphic RBCs, casts, proteinuria) point to nephrology workup, while non-glomerular sources (isomorphic RBCs, clots) require urologic evaluation including imaging and cystoscopy to rule out malignancy.
explanation.technical_details: Dysmorphic RBCs show membrane blebs, budding, and irregular shapes due to osmotic stress traversing the glomerular basement membrane. The AUA defines microscopic hematuria as ≥3 RBCs/HPF. Risk factors for malignancy include age ≥35, smoking, gross hematuria, irritative voiding symptoms, and chemical exposures.

definitions_glossary.hematuria: Presence of blood in urine; microscopic (≥3 RBCs/HPF) or gross (visible)
definitions_glossary.microscopic_hematuria: ≥3 RBCs per high-power field on urinalysis microscopy
definitions_glossary.gross_hematuria: Visible blood in urine; always requires full evaluation
definitions_glossary.dysmorphic_RBCs: Abnormally shaped RBCs indicating glomerular origin with membrane distortion
definitions_glossary.RBC_cast: Cylindrical structure containing RBCs; pathognomonic for glomerular bleeding
definitions_glossary.cystoscopy: Direct visualization of bladder interior using endoscope
definitions_glossary.CT_urography: CT imaging with IV contrast optimized for urinary tract evaluation
definitions_glossary.phase_contrast_microscopy: Technique to identify dysmorphic RBCs with enhanced morphologic detail
definitions_glossary.acanthocyte: Specific dysmorphic RBC with ring shape and membrane projections; G1 cells
definitions_glossary.myoglobinuria: Myoglobin in urine mimicking hematuria; dipstick positive but no RBCs
definitions_glossary.hemoglobinuria: Free hemoglobin in urine mimicking hematuria; no RBCs on microscopy
definitions_glossary.pyuria: White blood cells in urine; may accompany hematuria in UTI

pathophysiology.mechanism: Blood enters urine from disruption of vascular integrity at any level of the urinary tract

glomerular.mechanism: RBCs traverse damaged glomerular basement membrane, becoming dysmorphic

non_glomerular_upper_tract.mechanism: Bleeding from kidney parenchyma, renal pelvis, or ureter

non_glomerular_lower_tract.mechanism: Bleeding from bladder, prostate, or urethra

diagnostic_criteria.AUA_definition: ≥3 RBCs/HPF on properly collected urinalysis; confirm on repeat if initial positive

low_risk.recommendation: Repeat UA in 6 months; shared decision-making for cystoscopy

intermediate_risk.recommendation: Cystoscopy and renal ultrasound (or CT urography)

by_etiology.glomerulonephritis: Immunosuppression per specific diagnosis; ACE-I/ARB for proteinuria
by_etiology.nephrolithiasis: Hydration, analgesia, intervention for obstructing stones
by_etiology.bladder_cancer: TURBT, intravesical therapy, or cystectomy per staging
by_etiology.UTI: Appropriate antibiotics with repeat UA after treatment

observation_criteria: Exercise-induced hematuria: repeat UA after 72h rest
Isolated microscopic hematuria with negative workup: annual UA

definition.@value: A systematic diagnostic approach to identify the source and etiology of hematuria, distinguishing glomerular from non-glomerular causes through urinalysis, imaging, and cystoscopy

scopeNote.@value: Covers diagnostic evaluation of both microscopic and gross hematuria in adults, including risk stratification and referral criteria

learning_objectives: Define microscopic and gross hematuria using AUA criteria
Distinguish glomerular from non-glomerular hematuria by RBC morphology
Apply risk stratification to determine appropriate workup intensity
Identify indications for cystoscopy and CT urography
Recognize red flags requiring urgent urologic evaluation
clinical_pearls: >80% dysmorphic RBCs or acanthocytes >5% = glomerular source
RBC casts are pathognomonic for glomerular bleeding
Dipstick positive but no RBCs = myoglobinuria or hemoglobinuria
Gross hematuria ALWAYS needs full workup regardless of age
Anticoagulation does not cause hematuria - still evaluate
Post-menopausal women and men >50 with any hematuria: think malignancy
common_misconceptions: Anticoagulants explain hematuria - they unmask lesions, not cause bleeding
Exercise hematuria is always benign - still need follow-up to confirm resolution
Only gross hematuria needs workup - microscopic hematuria can indicate malignancy

citations.authors: Barocas DA, Boorjian SA, Alvarez RD, et al.
citations.title: Microhematuria: AUA/SUFU Guideline

citations.authors: Yun EJ, Meng MV, Carroll PR
citations.title: Evaluation of the patient with hematuria

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on AUA/SUFU 2020 guidelines for microhematuria evaluation

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
